title: 115_hr3345
content: The "Veterans Jobs Opportunity Act" includes a provision for a Veteran Small Business Start-Up Credit under section 45S of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Veterans Jobs Opportunity Act" provides a Veteran Small Business Start-Up Credit of 15% of qualified start-up expenditures, up to $80,000, for applicable veteran-owned businesses in underserved communities. Ownership and control criteria apply. The term 'small business' refers to a person engaged in a trade or business in the United States with gross receipts not exceeding $5,000,000 in the preceding taxable year. Ownership criteria vary based on business structure. The term 'underserved community' refers to areas within HUBZones, empowerment zones, enterprise communities, or low to moderate income areas. Businesses with less than 100 full-time employees may qualify. The term 'underserved community' includes low to moderate income areas, HUBZones, empowerment zones, and enterprise communities. Businesses with fewer than 100 full-time employees may qualify. Qualified start-up expenditures refer to expenses incurred for real estate purchase or lease. The taxpayer may elect to apply special rules for the first 2 taxable years for which expenses in carrying on a trade or business are deductible. Controlled groups are treated as one entity, and no double benefit is allowed for property eligible for a credit under this section. The basis of property is reduced by the credit amount. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. Section 45S introduces the veteran small business start-up credit as part of the general business credit. The Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration will evaluate the program every fourth year to assess its success and accountability. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act.
